awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Aerospace Engineering Research Opportunities for Undergraduates (AERO-U)
awd_abstract_narration:
This renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program, Aerospace Engineering Research Opportunities for Undergraduates (AERO-U) at Texas A&M University (TAMU) has at its overarching goal to encourage undergraduate students, especially underrepresented minorities and women, to pursue careers as researchers in aerospace engineering. Projects span a number of aerospace related research topics and will include new projects on the design of a bio-mimetic morphing wing, cyclocopters, and uninhabited autonomous vehicles.  Continuing research activities include projects on modeling and testing of electromagnetic field effects on hypersonic vehicle scramjet inlet, wing, stability and transition to turbulence and plasmas in propulsion and other fields (e.g. bio-medical, materials synthesis. Many of the research areas are critical to national goals for leadership in space exploration, future transportation needs, and homeland security.  

Over a three year period, this REU Site program will engage undergraduate students in a 10-week intensive, summer experience focused on conducting cutting-edge aerospace engineering research. The students will work on individualized projects, engage in community building activities with other REU students, TAMU undergraduates and graduate students, and TAMU faculty, receive professional development opportunities, receive tutoring concerning graduate school, and attend field trips which connect the research to real-world problems. Students to be recruited focus on underrepresented minorities and women nationwide and from the 18 universities in the TAMU Engineering Experiment Station (TEES) and many are minority serving institutions.  These include TAMU-Kingsville and TAMU-Corpus Christi, both Hispanic Serving institutions (HSI), and Prairie View A&M (PVAMU), an historically black college and university (HBCU). PVAMU and TAMU-Kingsville have established engineering programs, and other TEES institutions have emerging ones.

por.por_cntn:
At least 84% of the REU students are attending or plan to attend graduate school. In our surveys, over 70% of pre-2017 AERO-U participants credited the REU for their increased interest and knowledge of graduate school. Top REU participants went into the university's early-admission to graduate school program. Over 17 REU students presented or published with faculty since the original REU (Hara et al., 2018; Cai et al., 2017; Chen et al., 2017; Richard et al., 2015; Oehler et al., 2011; Richard et al., 2009; Bayeh et al., 2009; Suman et al., 2009; Araya and Rediniotis, 2008; Bayeh, 2008, Jan. and May; Carpenter et al., 2008; Deresz and Richard, 2008; Richard et al., 2008; Araya et al., 2007). Even participants entering the workforce planned to eventually go to graduate school or while working. Over 2/3 of the original (2006-2010) REU participants are going to graduate school or intended to do so. About 1/3 of them chose TAMU for graduate school. REU participants since 2010 plan to attend graduate school and at least get a Master's degree. The 2015 participants were the least certain of their plans. Seven of those planned to pursue a PhD. We admitted 49 of 690 applicants from 2016 to 2022. In line with our target of 60% women and minority students among the program participants, our admitted students included 71.7% women and minorities but only 57.1% of them accepted. A total of 38 students who are U.S. citizens or permanent residents, including Puerto Rico, participated in the REU for three 10-week summers of 2017 through 2022. Many students are attending or plan to attend similarly ranked universities  (e.g., Berkeley, Georgia Tech, Michigan, RPI, Stanford, USC, UT Austin). At least 5 students earned the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP). 

REU participants worked on numerical techniques vital to future developments in transportation at various companies. They showed new ways that companies could also implement new techniques, not just for aerospace vehicles, but other modes of transportation, and in other fields, such as use of plasmas in materials science and engineering. Even the research on using Martian and terrestrial atmospheric gases in magneto-plasma rockets and magnetic nozzles showed the other benefits of electric propulsion using other planet's materials for propellant or for future more efficient aircraft.  One student received certification for the Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI) training to be able to participate in human subjects research as required by the Texas A&M University Institutional Review Board (IRB) as she will be surveying the students in the course covered in the ASEE, FIE, and AERA papers. 

One major research and development from the REU relevant to the proposal is the work on the feasibility of an interactive e-text-book. We sought to discover the best methods to take advantage of the hardware and software currently available for eBooks and evaluate the feasibility of true interactivity for computationally intensive fields. We created various technical demos to prove and evaluate the viability of interactivity of ePubs including techniques such as utilizing Web Workers, pseudo-dynamic problem generation, and the transliteration of Lattice-Boltzmann code to JavaScript for near-real time fluid simulation of predefined cases at a spatial resolution of 642. We combined these into a sample textbook chapter (Richard et al. 2015).

The program participants benefited from Program Coordinator Dr. Richard's participation in the Summer 2012 REU Science Communication Workshop at the Museum of Science in Boston, MA, to help students better present their work. This workshop is held in accordance with the Nanoscale Informal Science Education Network (NISE Net), supported by NSF (Grant No. 0532536 and 0940143). The NISE Net is a national community of researchers and science educators who work to raise public awareness, engagement, and understanding of nanoscale science, engineering, and technology. We annually implement the workshop activities (modified for our weekly seminars) to help the students with their presentation skills, starting early in the summer but 2022 required maintaining some continuing precautions due to COVID-19 and a lot of information was shared online with the program participants.

Recent Publications

- Richard, J. C., & Yoon, S. Y. (2021), Three-Year Study of the Impact of a Research Experience Program in Aerospace Engineering on Undergraduate Students. Scholarship and Practice of Undergraduate Research (SPUR) Journal. Vol. 4, Iss. 4, 23-32. DOI:10.18833/spur/4/4/5.

-  Kumar ,Prabhat, Derek Kuldinow, Andres Castillo, Alexandros Gerakis, and Kentaro Hara. (2021). Nonlinear dynamics of coupled light and particle beam propagation. Physical Review A. 103, 043502. DOI:10.1103/PhysRevA.103.043502

- DesJardin, I., Hara, K., & Tsikata, S., (2019). Self-organized standing waves generated by AC-driven electron cyclotron drift instabilities, Appl. Phys. Lett. (115)234103. https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5131019  

- Richard, Jacques C., Collins, Logan N., Shryock, Kristi, J., Whitcomb, John D. and Angarita, John E.. Feasibility of interactive eTextbooks with computationally intense content, Computers in Education Division of ASEE, Vol. 6, No. 2, April - June 2015.
